questions.hint: It's one of the most prestigious law schools in the United States.
questions.fact: Mike Ross' fraudulent Harvard degree is a central plot point throughout the series, constantly putting his career at risk.

questions.question: In Suits, what is Louis Litt's cat's name?
questions.hint: The cat shares its name with a human character from the show.
questions.fact: Louis named his cat Esther after his sister, showing his deep affection for both his pet and his family.

questions.question: In Suits, what is Donna's last name?
questions.hint: It's the same as her first name mentioned earlier.
questions.fact: Donna Paulsen's full name is Donna Roberta Paulsen, though her middle name is rarely mentioned in the show.

questions.question: In Game of Thrones, who was the first character to die in the series?
questions.hint: He was a member of the Night's Watch.
questions.fact: Will, a ranger of the Night's Watch, is beheaded by Ned Stark in the first episode for deserting his post after encountering White Walkers.

questions.question: In Game of Thrones, what is the name of Arya Stark's sword?
questions.hint: It's a thin sword, perfect for Arya's water dancing style.
questions.fact: Needle was given to Arya by her half-brother Jon Snow before he left for the Night's Watch.

questions.question: In Game of Thrones, what are Daenerys Targaryen's three dragons called?
questions.hint: They are named after important figures in Daenerys' life.
questions.fact: Drogon is named after Khal Drogo, Rhaegal after Rhaegar Targaryen, and Viserion after Viserys Targaryen.

questions.question: In Game of Thrones, what is the name of the continent where most of the story takes place?
questions.hint: It's where the Seven Kingdoms are located.
questions.fact: Westeros is roughly based on medieval Britain, with the North inspired by Scotland and the Wall inspired by Hadrian's Wall.

questions.question: In How I Met Your Mother, what is the name of Barney's playbook?
questions.hint: It contains all of Barney's elaborate schemes to pick up women.
questions.fact: The Playbook contains over 200 schemes that Barney uses throughout the series to seduce women.

questions.question: In The Witcher, what is the name of Geralt's horse?
questions.hint: It's the name of a type of fish.
questions.fact: Interestingly, Geralt names all of his horses Roach, regardless of their gender or appearance.

questions.question: In The Mandalorian, what is the real name of 'Baby Yoda'?
questions.hint: His name was revealed in the second season of the show.
questions.fact: The name Grogu was kept a closely guarded secret during production, with the character being referred to as 'The Child' or 'The Asset' in scripts and on set.

questions.question: In Friends, what is the name of Ross's second wife?
questions.hint: She's British and their marriage was very short-lived.
questions.fact: Ross accidentally says Rachel's name instead of Emily's during their wedding vows, leading to the quick demise of their marriage.

questions.question: In the pilot episode of Friends, what was the first line spoken by Rachel?
options: Oh God, Monica, hi! Thank God.
questions.hint: She says this when she enters Central Perk in a wedding dress.
questions.fact: This line marks Rachel's dramatic entrance into the series, setting up her character's storyline for the first season.

questions.question: In Friends, what was the name of Chandler's annoying ex-girlfriend?
questions.hint: She's known for her distinctive laugh and catchphrase 'Oh. My. God!'
questions.fact: Janice, played by Maggie Wheeler, was originally intended to appear in only one episode but became a recurring character due to her popularity with fans.

questions.question: In Friends, which character originally said the phrase, 'We were on a break'?
questions.hint: This character uses this phrase to justify his actions during a temporary breakup.
questions.fact: The phrase 'We were on a break' becomes a running gag throughout the series, often used by Ross to defend his actions.

questions.question: In Friends, what is the name of the character who famously says, 'Could I BE any moreâ€¦?' followed by various comedic statements?
questions.hint: This character is known for his sarcastic humor and awkwardness.
questions.fact: Matthew Perry, who played Chandler, actually came up with this catchphrase himself during rehearsals.

questions.question: In Friends, what was the name of Joey's stuffed penguin that he carried around for years?
questions.hint: The name sounds similar to 'hugs'.
questions.fact: Hugsy is described as Joey's 'bedtime penguin pal' and becomes a source of conflict when Joey has to share it with Emma, Rachel and Ross's daughter.

questions.question: In Friends, who was Monica's first roommate in New York before Rachel moved in?
questions.hint: This character later moves out because she can't stand Monica's obsessive cleanliness.
questions.fact: Phoebe lived with Monica before the start of the series, but moved out and in with her grandmother. This is why Phoebe has her own apartment when the series begins.

questions.question: Which Indian scientist's work on 'wireless communication' was acknowledged by the Nobel committee during Guglielmo Marconi's Nobel Prize acceptance speech?
questions.hint: He was a pioneer in the study of radio and microwave optics.
questions.fact: Jagadish Chandra Bose's work on millimeter wavelengths and his invention of an early version of wireless telecommunication were groundbreaking, though often overlooked in the West.

questions.question: Which ancient Indian university, considered one of the oldest in the world, was located in present-day Bihar?
questions.hint: It was a renowned center of learning from the 5th century CE to 1200 CE.
questions.fact: Nalanda University was so vast that it reportedly accommodated over 10,000 students and 2,000 teachers at its peak, attracting scholars from Tibet, China, Korea, and Central Asia.

questions.question: Who was the Indian mathematician who discovered the 'Madhava-Leibniz series' for Ï€, about 250 years before Leibniz?
questions.hint: He was a 14th-century mathematician from Kerala.
questions.fact: Madhava of Sangamagrama made significant contributions to calculus and trigonometry centuries before their development in Europe, including infinite series approximations for sine, cosine, and arctangent functions.

questions.question: Which Indian freedom fighter and revolutionary is known for his book 'Indian War of Independence 1857' and his efforts to establish the India House in London?
questions.hint: He was also known as 'Veer Savarkar'.
questions.fact: Vinayak Damodar Savarkar's book 'Indian War of Independence 1857' was banned by the British government before its publication in India, but was smuggled and published in the Netherlands, Germany, and France.

questions.question: Which Indian classical music instrument, despite its name, does not have any strings?
questions.hint: This instrument uses water-filled porcelain bowls.
questions.fact: Jaltarang, meaning 'waves of water', is played by striking the rims of water-filled porcelain bowls with sticks, producing different notes based on the water levels in the bowls.

questions.question: Which Indian state was the first to achieve 100% primary education?
questions.hint: This northeastern state achieved this milestone in 2014.
questions.fact: Mizoram achieved 100% primary education in 2014, with a literacy rate of 91.33%, second only to Kerala in India.

questions.question: Who was the Indian physicist who worked with Albert Einstein on the Bose-Einstein condensate theory?
questions.hint: The 'boson' particle is named after him.
questions.fact: Satyendra Nath Bose's work on quantum mechanics, particularly the Bose-Einstein condensate, laid the foundation for modern atomic theory and the discovery of the Higgs boson.

questions.question: Which Indian king's navy was so powerful that he was known as the 'Lord of the Eastern and Western Seas'?
questions.hint: He ruled the Chola dynasty in the 11th century CE.
questions.fact: Raja Raja Chola I's naval power extended the Chola influence to Southeast Asian countries like Indonesia, Malaysia, and southern Thailand.

questions.question: Which Indian scientist's work on cosmic rays led to the discovery of the muon particle?
questions.hint: He was the founding director of the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research.
questions.fact: Homi J. Bhabha, along with Walter Heitler, made significant contributions to the understanding of cosmic ray showers, which led to the discovery of the muon particle.

questions.question: Which ancient Indian text is considered the world's first book on economics?
questions.hint: This text was written by Chanakya, also known as Kautilya.
questions.fact: The Arthashastra, written around 300 BCE, covers topics such as statecraft, economic policy, and military strategy, and is considered a pioneering work in political science and economics.

questions.question: Which Indian mathematician is credited with solving Fermat's Last Theorem for the n=4 case, long before it was fully solved?
questions.hint: He lived in the 12th century and wrote the Siddhanta Siromani.
questions.fact: Bhaskara II provided a proof for the n=4 case of Fermat's Last Theorem in the 12th century, about 750 years before it was fully solved by Andrew Wiles in 1995.

questions.question: Which Indian classical dance form incorporates martial arts movements and is native to Kerala?
questions.hint: This dance form is known for its elaborate makeup and costumes.
questions.fact: Kathakali incorporates elements from Kalaripayattu, an ancient Indian martial art form, in its movements and gestures.

questions.question: Which Indian scientist's work on plant physiology led to the discovery of the phenomenon of 'plant nervous system'?
questions.hint: He invented the crescograph to measure plant response to stimuli.
questions.fact: Jagadish Chandra Bose's experiments showed that plants have a system similar to the nervous system of animals, responding to stimuli like light, sound, and touch.

questions.question: Which Indian freedom fighter is known for establishing the 'Abhinav Bharat Society' and was sentenced to two life terms at the Cellular Jail?
questions.hint: He was also known as 'Swatantryaveer' or 'Veer'.
questions.fact: Vinayak Damodar Savarkar was sentenced to 50 years in the Cellular Jail (Kala Pani) in the Andaman Islands but was released after 10 years due to political pressure.

questions.question: Which Indian ruler's navy was the first to defeat a European naval power in a sea battle?
questions.hint: He established the Maratha Empire in the 17th century.
questions.fact: Shivaji's navy, under the command of Kanhoji Angre, defeated the British, Dutch, and Portuguese navies multiple times, making it the first Asian navy to successfully challenge European naval powers.

questions.question: Which Indian environmental activist is known for the 'Chipko Movement' and received the Right Livelihood Award in 1987?
questions.hint: He was also involved in the anti-Tehri Dam protests.
questions.fact: Sunderlal Bahuguna's Chipko Movement, which involved hugging trees to prevent deforestation, became a model for non-violent environmental protests worldwide.

questions.question: Which Indian physicist's work on quantum mechanics and particle physics led to the prediction of the 'Tachyon', a hypothetical particle that travels faster than light?
questions.hint: He also made significant contributions to the field of quantum optics.
questions.fact: E.C.G. Sudarshan's work on tachyons, though controversial, has influenced theoretical physics and science fiction. He was also known for the Sudarshan-Glauber representation in quantum optics.

questions.question: Which ancient Indian university, located in present-day Odisha, was known for its School of Logic and Philosophy?
questions.hint: It was one of the largest Buddhist monasteries in ancient India.
questions.fact: Pushpagiri University, along with Nalanda and Takshashila, was one of the oldest universities in the world. It was particularly renowned for its schools of logic, philosophy, and Buddhist tantra.

questions.question: Which Indian mathematician made significant contributions to the theory of partitions and was mentored by G.H. Hardy?
questions.hint: He is known for the 'Ramanujan prime' and 'Ramanujan theta function'.
questions.fact: Srinivasa Ramanujan, despite having almost no formal training in pure mathematics, made extraordinary contributions to mathematical analysis, number theory, infinite series, and continued fractions.

questions.question: Which Indian classical music instrument was modified by Allauddin Khan to be played as a solo instrument?
questions.hint: This instrument is a stringed instrument with a fretless fingerboard.
questions.fact: Allauddin Khan modified the sarod by adding metal strings and a metal fingerboard, allowing for greater versatility and making it suitable for solo performances in Hindustani classical music.

questions.question: Which Indian scientist's work on radio waves and the ionosphere led to the development of long-distance radio communication?
questions.hint: He wrote the book 'The Upper Atmosphere'.
questions.fact: S.K. Mitra's research on the ionosphere and its effects on radio wave propagation was crucial for the development of long-distance radio communication and laid the foundation for modern wireless communication technologies.

questions.question: Which Indian ruler's administration system, known as 'Ashtapradhan', is considered a precursor to the modern cabinet system?
questions.hint: He founded the Maratha Empire in the 17th century.
questions.fact: Shivaji's Ashtapradhan (Council of Eight Ministers) was a sophisticated administrative system that divided responsibilities among ministers, similar to modern cabinet governments.

questions.question: Which Indian scientist's work on plant breeding led to the development of high-yielding varieties of wheat and rice, contributing significantly to India's Green Revolution?
questions.hint: He is often referred to as the 'Father of Indian Green Revolution'.
questions.fact: M.S. Swaminathan's work on developing high-yielding varieties of wheat and rice helped India achieve food self-sufficiency in the 1970s and earned him the first World Food Prize in 1987.

questions.question: Which ancient Indian text, written by Bharata Muni, is considered the foundational treatise on dramatic arts and aesthetics?
questions.hint: This text is often called the 'Fifth Veda'.
questions.fact: The Natyashastra, written between 200 BCE and 200 CE, covers various aspects of dramatic composition, theater architecture, makeup techniques, and rasa theory, which forms the basis of Indian aesthetics and has influenced various forms of Indian classical dance and music.

questions.question: Which Indian mathematician made significant contributions to the field of differential geometry and is known for the 'Chandrasekhar limit' in astrophysics?
questions.hint: He won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1983.
questions.fact: Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar's work on the evolution of stars led to the discovery of the Chandrasekhar limit, which explains the maximum mass of a stable white dwarf star.

questions.question: Which Indian freedom fighter and philosopher propounded the concept of 'Integral Humanism'?
questions.hint: He was associated with the Bharatiya Jana Sangh, the predecessor of the BJP.
questions.fact: Deendayal Upadhyaya's philosophy of Integral Humanism sought to create a distinctively Indian political philosophy, synthesizing elements from ancient Indian thought with modern political ideas.

questions.question: What is the only country to have a flag that is not quadrilateral in shape?
questions.hint: This country's flag has two triangles.
questions.fact: Nepal's flag is the world's only non-quadrilateral national flag. It is made of two triangles representing the Himalayan mountains and the two major religions, Hinduism and Buddhism.

questions.question: What is the rarest blood type in the world?
questions.hint: This blood type has no Rh antigen.
questions.fact: Rh-null, sometimes called 'golden blood', is the rarest blood type in the world. Only about 43 people worldwide have been reported to have this blood type.

questions.question: What element does "O" represent on the periodic table?
questions.hint: This element is essential for respiration.
questions.fact: Oxygen is the third-most abundant element in the universe and makes up about 21% of the Earth's atmosphere.

questions.question: Which ancient civilization built the Machu Picchu?
questions.hint: This civilization flourished in the Andes.
questions.fact: Machu Picchu was built around 1450 AD and was abandoned just over 100 years later during the Spanish Conquest. It was rediscovered in 1911 by Hiram Bingham.

questions.question: What is the longest-running science fiction television series?
questions.hint: This British series first aired in 1963.
questions.fact: Doctor Who first aired on November 23, 1963, and has since become a significant part of British popular culture. It has aired over 850 episodes across 39 seasons.

questions.question: What is the most distant planet in our solar system?
questions.hint: This dwarf planet lies beyond Pluto.
questions.fact: Eris is a dwarf planet in the scattered disc of the Solar System. It is about 68 AU from the Sun, making it the most distant known natural object in the Solar System.

questions.question: In what year did the Chernobyl nuclear disaster occur?
questions.hint: This disaster occurred in Ukraine, then part of the Soviet Union.
questions.fact: The Chernobyl disaster was a nuclear accident that occurred on April 26, 1986, at the No. 4 reactor in the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant, near the city of Pripyat in the north of the Ukrainian SSR.

questions.question: What is the capital of Kazakhstan?
questions.hint: This city was renamed Nur-Sultan in 2019.
questions.fact: Astana, now known as Nur-Sultan, became the capital of Kazakhstan in 1997, replacing Almaty. It was renamed in honor of former President Nursultan Nazarbayev in 2019.

questions.question: Which physicist developed the uncertainty principle?
questions.hint: This principle states that the position and velocity of a particle cannot both be precisely determined at the same time.
questions.fact: Werner Heisenberg formulated the uncertainty principle in 1927. It is one of the cornerstones of quantum mechanics and has profound implications for our understanding of the nature of reality.

questions.question: Who won the first Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1901?
questions.hint: This scientist was awarded for his discovery of the laws of osmosis.
questions.fact: Jacobus Henricus van 't Hoff was awarded the first Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his work on chemical dynamics and osmotic pressure in solutions.

questions.question: What was the first artificial satellite to orbit the Earth?
questions.hint: This satellite was launched by the Soviet Union in 1957.
questions.fact: Sputnik 1 was launched on October 4, 1957, and orbited Earth for three months before its batteries died. Its launch marked the start of the Space Age and the U.S.-USSR Space Race.

questions.question: Which country was formerly known as Ceylon?
questions.hint: This island nation is located off the southern coast of India.
questions.fact: Sri Lanka was known as Ceylon until 1972. The name change was part of a broader decolonization process after gaining independence from British rule in 1948.

questions.question: What is the largest known star by radius and volume?
questions.hint: This star is located in the constellation of Scutum.
questions.fact: UY Scuti is a hypergiant star with a radius estimated to be around 1,700 times larger than the Sun. If placed at the center of our solar system, its surface would extend beyond the orbit of Jupiter.

questions.question: In Greek mythology, who was the goddess of wisdom?
questions.hint: This goddess was born from the head of Zeus.
questions.fact: Athena is also associated with war strategy, crafts, and justice. Her symbol is the owl, and her sacred plant is the olive tree.

questions.question: Who is credited with the invention of the first mechanical computer?
questions.hint: This British mathematician is known as the "father of the computer."
questions.fact: Charles Babbage designed the Difference Engine in the 1820s and later the more general Analytical Engine. While never fully built in his lifetime, these designs are considered precursors to modern computers.

questions.question: Who is the only U.S. president to have served more than two terms?
questions.hint: This president served four terms during the Great Depression and World War II.
questions.fact: Franklin D. Roosevelt served from 1933 until his death in 1945. After his presidency, the 22nd Amendment was passed, limiting presidents to two terms.

questions.question: What is the name of the longest-running comic strip in the world?
questions.hint: This comic strip, created by Charles Schulz, ran from 1950 to 2000.
questions.fact: Peanuts ran for nearly 50 years, featuring iconic characters like Charlie Brown and Snoopy. It appeared in over 2,600 newspapers, with a readership of 355 million in 75 countries.

questions.question: What is the third largest continent by land area?
questions.hint: This continent is home to the United States and Canada.
questions.fact: North America covers an area of about 24.7 million square kilometers (9.5 million square miles), making it the third-largest continent after Asia and Africa.

questions.question: Which scientist is best known for formulating the laws of motion and universal gravitation?
questions.hint: His famous work is "PhilosophiÃ¦ Naturalis Principia Mathematica."
questions.fact: Isaac Newton's laws of motion and universal gravitation, published in 1687, remained the foundation of classical mechanics for the next three centuries until Einstein's theory of relativity.

questions.question: Who wrote the novel "One Hundred Years of Solitude"?
questions.hint: This novel is a cornerstone of Latin American magical realism.
questions.fact: Gabriel GarcÃ­a MÃ¡rquez's novel, published in 1967, is considered one of the most significant works in the Spanish literary canon. It has been translated into 46 languages and sold over 50 million copies.

questions.question: What was the first country to grant women the right to vote?
questions.hint: This country gave women the right to vote in 1893.
questions.fact: New Zealand was the first self-governing country in the world to grant all women the right to vote in parliamentary elections. The Electoral Act 1893 was passed on 19 September 1893.

questions.question: In which year did the Titanic sink?
questions.hint: This disaster occurred during its maiden voyage.
questions.fact: The RMS Titanic sank in the early morning hours of April 15, 1912, after striking an iceberg during her maiden voyage from Southampton to New York City. Over 1,500 people lost their lives in the disaster.

questions.question: What is the capital of Bhutan?
questions.hint: This city is known for its traditional architecture and Buddhist culture.
questions.fact: Thimphu became the capital of Bhutan in 1961. It is the largest city in the country and is known for its unique blend of modern development and traditional Bhutanese culture.

questions.question: Who invented the first successful steam engine?
questions.hint: This Scottish inventor's improvements revolutionized industry.
questions.fact: While James Watt didn't invent the steam engine, his improvements to the Newcomen steam engine were crucial. His steam engine design, patented in 1769, became a key driver of the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question: Which emperor built the Great Wall of China?
questions.hint: This emperor is also known for his terracotta army.
questions.fact: Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China, began the construction of the Great Wall around 220 BCE. However, much of what we see today was built during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644).

questions.question: Which element has the highest melting point?
questions.hint: This metal is used in lightbulb filaments and aerospace applications.
questions.fact: Tungsten has the highest melting point of any metal at 3,422Â°C (6,192Â°F). This property makes it useful in applications involving extreme heat, such as lightbulb filaments and rocket engine nozzles.

questions.question: Which is the largest living organism on Earth by area?
questions.hint: This organism is a type of fungus in Oregon.
questions.fact: The largest known organism is a honey fungus (Armillaria ostoyae) in Oregon's Malheur National Forest. It covers an area of about 2,385 acres (965 hectares) and is estimated to be 2,400-8,650 years old.

questions.question: What was the first artificial Earth satellite?
questions.hint: Launched by the Soviet Union in 1957, it marked the beginning of the Space Age.
questions.fact: Sputnik 1 was launched on October 4, 1957. It was a 58 cm (23 in) diameter polished metal sphere, with four external radio antennas to broadcast radio pulses. Its launch marked the start of the Space Age.

questions.question: Who was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize?
questions.hint: She won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903.
questions.fact: Marie Curie was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the first person to win two Nobel Prizes. She won the Physics Prize in 1903 (shared with her husband) and the Chemistry Prize in 1911.

questions.question: What was the first video game to feature the character Mario?
questions.hint: This arcade game introduced Mario as "Jumpman."
questions.fact: Mario first appeared as 'Jumpman' in the 1981 arcade game Donkey Kong. He was renamed Mario in the 1982 game Mario Bros., where he was joined by his brother Luigi. Since then, Mario has become one of the most recognizable video game characters in the world and the mascot of Nintendo.

questions.question: What is the chemical symbol for the element tungsten?
questions.hint: This element's symbol comes from its German name "Wolfram."
questions.fact: Tungsten's chemical symbol 'W' comes from its old German name, 'wolfram'. It has the highest melting point of all elements and is used in light bulb filaments and armor-piercing ammunition.

questions.question: Who is known as the "father of modern chemistry"?
questions.hint: He helped to establish the Law of Conservation of Mass.
questions.fact: Antoine Lavoisier (1743-1794) is considered the 'father of modern chemistry'. He discovered the role oxygen plays in combustion, helped to establish the metric system, and named hydrogen.

questions.question: What is the hardest substance on Earth?
questions.hint: This substance is often used in cutting tools and jewelry.
questions.fact: Diamond is the hardest known natural material on Earth. It's made of pure carbon and scores a 10 on the Mohs scale of mineral hardness. Synthetic nanomaterials like wurtzite boron nitride can be harder.

questions.question: Which scientist discovered the circulation of blood?
questions.hint: This discovery revolutionized the understanding of human anatomy.
questions.fact: William Harvey described the circulation of blood in his book 'De Motu Cordis' in 1628. This discovery overturned the long-standing theories of the Greek physician Galen and revolutionized medicine.

questions.question: Who is credited with inventing the first practical light bulb?
questions.hint: He is also known for his work with electricity and the phonograph.
questions.fact: While Thomas Edison didn't invent the first electric light, he created the first commercially successful incandescent light bulb in 1879. His version could last for 40 hours without burning out.

questions.question: What was the first city to reach a population of 1 million?
questions.hint: This city reached that milestone in the early 19th century.
questions.fact: London became the first city in the modern era to reach a population of 1 million around 1810. However, it's believed that Rome may have reached this milestone during the peak of the Roman Empire.

questions.question: What does the term 'Armageddon' refer to in Christian theology?
questions.hint: This term is often used to describe a final, catastrophic event.
questions.fact: In Christian theology, Armageddon refers to the final battle between good and evil that will occur at the end of the world. The term comes from a location mentioned in the Book of Revelation.

questions.question: Which country was the first to launch a human-made satellite into space?
questions.hint: This country launched Sputnik 1 in 1957.
questions.fact: The Soviet Union launched Sputnik 1 on October 4, 1957, marking the start of the Space Age. This launch also initiated the Space Race between the Soviet Union and the United States.

questions.question: Who is the author of the novel "The Catcher in the Rye"?
questions.hint: This novel is a classic of 20th-century American literature.
questions.fact: J.D. Salinger published 'The Catcher in the Rye' in 1951. The novel's protagonist, Holden Caulfield, has become an icon for teenage rebellion and angst. Salinger became a recluse after its publication.

questions.question: Which artist is famous for the painting "The Persistence of Memory"?
questions.hint: This surrealist painting features melting clocks.
questions.fact: Salvador DalÃ­ painted 'The Persistence of Memory' in 1931. It's one of the most recognizable works of Surrealism, featuring soft, melting pocket watches in a barren landscape.

questions.question: What is the world's largest desert?
questions.hint: This desert is cold and covers much of Antarctica.
questions.fact: The Antarctic Desert is the largest desert in the world, covering an area of about 5.5 million square miles. Deserts are defined by low precipitation, not necessarily high temperatures.

questions.question: Who was the first woman in space?
questions.hint: This Soviet cosmonaut flew into space in 1963.
questions.fact: Valentina Tereshkova became the first woman in space on June 16, 1963, when she flew aboard Vostok 6. She orbited Earth 48 times during her three-day mission.

questions.question: What is the name of the largest moon of Saturn?
questions.hint: This moon is larger than the planet Mercury.
questions.fact: Titan is Saturn's largest moon and the second-largest natural satellite in our Solar System. It's the only moon known to have a dense atmosphere, and the only celestial body other than Earth where evidence of stable bodies of surface liquid has been found.

questions.question: Which country is the largest producer of olive oil?
questions.hint: This country produces over half of the world's olive oil.
questions.fact: Spain is the world's largest producer of olive oil, accounting for about 44% of global production. The country has over 300 million olive trees, and olive oil production is a major industry, especially in the southern region of Andalusia.

questions.question: What does "www" stand for in a website address?
questions.hint: This acronym refers to the internet's global network of websites.
questions.fact: WWW stands for World Wide Web. It was invented by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989 while working at CERN. The World Wide Web is an information system where documents and other resources are identified by URLs, interlinked by hypertext links, and can be accessed over the Internet.

questions.question: What was the first video game character to get a balloon in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade?
questions.hint: This character is from a famous video game franchise created by Nintendo.
questions.fact: Mario, Nintendo's iconic plumber, became the first video game character to have a balloon in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade in 1993. This marked a significant moment in recognizing video games as a mainstream form of entertainment.

questions.question: Which planet has the shortest day?
questions.hint: This planet's day is just under 10 hours long.
questions.fact: Jupiter has the shortest day of all the planets in the Solar System, completing one rotation in just 9 hours and 56 minutes. Despite being the largest planet, its rapid rotation causes it to bulge at the equator and flatten at the poles.

questions.question: Which civilization created the first known writing system?
questions.hint: This system, cuneiform, was developed around 3000 BCE.
questions.fact: The Sumerians, who lived in ancient Mesopotamia (modern-day Iraq), developed cuneiform around 3000 BCE. This writing system began as pictographs and evolved into a complex system of wedge-shaped marks pressed into clay tablets.

questions.question: Which country is credited with inventing the first paper?
questions.hint: The Chinese invented paper during the Han Dynasty.
questions.fact: Paper was invented in China during the Han Dynasty (202 BCE - 220 CE). Traditionally, its invention is attributed to Cai Lun, an official of the Imperial court, around 105 CE. The technology slowly spread westward, reaching Europe in the 11th century.

questions.question: What is the capital city of Iceland?
questions.hint: This city is known for its geothermal hot springs.
questions.fact: Reykjavik is the capital and largest city of Iceland. It's the world's northernmost capital of a sovereign state and is known for its geothermal hot springs, vibrant culture, and proximity to stunning natural landscapes.

questions.question: Who was the first person to circumnavigate the globe?
questions.hint: Magellan's expedition completed the journey after his death.
questions.fact: Ferdinand Magellan's expedition was the first to circumnavigate the globe, but Magellan himself died in the Philippines in 1521. The expedition was completed in 1522 under the command of Juan SebastiÃ¡n Elcano.

questions.question: Who is credited with discovering penicillin?
questions.hint: This discovery revolutionized medicine in the 20th century.
questions.fact: Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin accidentally in 1928 when he noticed that mold had contaminated one of his petri dishes and was killing the bacteria he was growing. This discovery led to the development of antibiotics, revolutionizing medicine.

questions.question: What is the tallest mountain in North America?
questions.hint: This mountain is located in Alaska.
questions.fact: Mount Denali, formerly known as Mount McKinley, is the highest peak in North America at 20,310 feet (6,190 meters) above sea level. It's located in Alaska's Denali National Park and is part of the Alaska Range.

questions.question: Which is the smallest country in the world by population?
questions.hint: This country is an independent city-state entirely surrounded by Rome.
questions.fact: Vatican City, with a population of around 825 (as of 2019), is the smallest country in the world by population. It's an independent city-state surrounded by Rome, Italy, and is the headquarters of the Roman Catholic Church.

questions.question: Who invented the first successful airplane?
questions.hint: Their first flight occurred in 1903 in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
questions.fact: Orville and Wilbur Wright made the first controlled, sustained flight of a powered, heavier-than-air aircraft on December 17, 1903, near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina. Their Wright Flyer flew for 12 seconds and covered 120 feet.

questions.question: Which is the longest river in the world?
questions.hint: This river is located in South America.
questions.fact: The Amazon River is considered the longest river in the world, with a length of about 6,400 kilometers (4,000 miles). It carries more water than any other river, with an average discharge greater than the next seven largest rivers combined.

questions.question: Who was the first actor to play James Bond in a movie?
questions.hint: He starred in the 1962 film Dr. No.
questions.fact: Sean Connery was the first actor to portray James Bond in the EON Productions film series, starting with 'Dr. No' in 1962. He played Bond in seven films and is often regarded as the definitive portrayal of the character.

questions.question: What is the largest organ in the human body?
questions.hint: This organ serves as a protective barrier for the body.
questions.fact: The skin is the largest organ in the human body, with a surface area of about 20 square feet in adults. It serves as a protective barrier, regulates body temperature, and is crucial for the sense of touch.

questions.question: Who developed the theory of general relativity?
questions.hint: This theory describes the relationship between space, time, and gravity.
questions.fact: Albert Einstein developed the theory of general relativity, which he published in 1915. This theory describes gravity as a consequence of the curvature of spacetime caused by mass and energy, revolutionizing our understanding of the universe.

questions.question: What is the primary ingredient in traditional French ratatouille?
questions.hint: This vegetable is often combined with other seasonal ingredients.
questions.fact: Ratatouille is a traditional French ProvenÃ§al dish that originated in Nice. While it includes various vegetables, eggplant is often considered the primary ingredient. The dish typically also includes tomatoes, zucchini, bell peppers, and onions, all simmered together with herbs.

questions.question: What is the smallest bone in the human body?
questions.hint: This bone is located in the ear.
questions.fact: The stapes, also known as the stirrup, is the smallest bone in the human body. It is one of three tiny bones in the middle ear and plays a crucial role in transmitting sound vibrations from the air to the inner ear.

questions.question: Which chemical element has the atomic number 79?
questions.hint: This metal is highly valued for its rarity and beauty.
questions.fact: Gold has the atomic number 79. It's a dense, soft, malleable, and ductile metal. Gold has been used for coinage, jewelry, and other arts throughout recorded history. It's also used in electronics and other high-tech applications.

questions.question: Which artist is famous for painting the Sistine Chapel ceiling?
questions.hint: This Renaissance artist painted one of the most famous works in the Vatican.
questions.fact: Michelangelo painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel between 1508 and 1512. The work includes over 300 figures and is considered one of the most significant works of Western art. It took four years to complete, with Michelangelo working on scaffolding.

questions.question: Who is the Greek god of the sea?
questions.hint: This god wields a trident.
questions.fact: Poseidon is the Greek god of the sea, earthquakes, storms, and horses. He is one of the twelve Olympian deities and is often depicted holding a trident. His Roman equivalent is Neptune.

questions.question: What is the capital of Norway?
questions.hint: This city is located at the head of the Oslofjord.
questions.fact: Oslo is the capital and most populous city of Norway. It was founded as a city in 1040 and became the capital of Norway in 1299. Oslo is a hub of Norwegian trade, banking, industry, and shipping.

questions.question: Which planet has the most moons?
questions.hint: This planet has over 80 confirmed moons.
questions.fact: Jupiter has the most moons of any planet in our solar system. As of 2023, it has 95 confirmed moons, with potentially more awaiting confirmation. Saturn is a close second with 83 confirmed moons.

questions.question: What is the name of the longest-running Broadway musical?
questions.hint: This musical has been performed since 1988.
questions.fact: The Phantom of the Opera is the longest-running show in Broadway history. It opened on January 26, 1988, and had its final performance on April 16, 2023, after 13,981 performances over 35 years.

questions.question: Who wrote the novel "1984"?
questions.hint: This novel is set in a dystopian future under totalitarian rule.
questions.fact: George Orwell wrote '1984', which was published in 1949. The novel is set in a totalitarian society and introduces concepts like 'Big Brother', 'doublethink', and 'Newspeak'. It's considered one of the most influential novels of the 20th century.

questions.question: Which is the only planet in our solar system that rotates clockwise?
questions.hint: This planet has a retrograde rotation.
questions.fact: Venus is the only planet in our solar system that rotates clockwise on its axis (retrograde rotation). All other planets rotate counterclockwise. This unique rotation might be due to a collision with another large body early in its history.

questions.question: Who first proposed the heliocentric theory?
questions.hint: This astronomer suggested that the Sun is at the center of the solar system.
questions.fact: Nicolaus Copernicus first proposed the heliocentric theory in his book 'De revolutionibus orbium coelestium' (On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres), published in 1543. This theory placed the Sun at the center of the universe, contradicting the prevailing geocentric model.

questions.question: Who is credited with inventing the first computer program?
questions.fact: Ada Lovelace is credited with writing the first computer program in the mid-1800s for Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine.
questions.hint: This mathematician worked with Charles Babbage on the Analytical Engine.

questions.question: What does 'HTTP' stand for in web addresses?
questions.fact: HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is the foundation of data communication on the World Wide Web.
questions.hint: This protocol is used for transferring web pages on the internet.

questions.question: In what year was the first iPhone released?
questions.fact: The first iPhone was introduced by Steve Jobs on January 9, 2007, and released to the public on June 29, 2007.
questions.hint: This revolutionary smartphone was introduced by Apple in the late 2000s.

questions.question: Which programming language is primarily used for iOS application development?
questions.fact: Swift was introduced by Apple in 2014 as a replacement for Objective-C and is now the primary language for iOS development.
questions.hint: This language was developed by Apple specifically for iOS and macOS development.

questions.question: What does the acronym 'RAM' stand for?
questions.fact: RAM is a type of computer memory that can be read and changed in any order, typically used to store working data and machine code.
questions.hint: This type of memory allows data to be read or written in almost the same amount of time irrespective of the physical location of data inside the memory.

questions.question: What was the first ever website?
questions.fact: The first website, created by Tim Berners-Lee, went live on August 6, 1991, at CERN.
questions.hint: This website was created at CERN, where the World Wide Web was invented.

questions.question: What year was the first Apple Macintosh computer released?
questions.fact: The first Apple Macintosh was released on January 24, 1984, and was the first personal computer to feature a graphical user interface.
questions.hint: This iconic computer was introduced with a famous Super Bowl commercial directed by Ridley Scott.

questions.question: Who is the founder of Tesla Motors?
questions.fact: While Elon Musk is often associated as the founder, Tesla was actually founded by Martin Eberhard and Marc Tarpenning in 2003. Musk joined in 2004 and became chairman of the board.
questions.hint: This entrepreneur is also known for founding SpaceX and co-founding PayPal.

questions.question: What was the first commercially successful video game?
questions.fact: Pong, released by Atari in 1972, was the first commercially successful video game and helped establish the video game industry.
questions.hint: This simple table tennis simulation game was released by Atari in 1972.

questions.question: Which company created the first optical mouse?
questions.fact: The first optical mouse was invented by Richard F. Lyon at Xerox in 1980, although it didn't become widely used until the late 1990s.
questions.hint: This company is better known for its photocopiers than computer peripherals.

questions.question: What does the 'BIOS' stand for in computer systems?
questions.fact: BIOS is firmware used to perform hardware initialization during the booting process and to provide runtime services for operating systems and programs.
questions.hint: This low-level software initializes hardware during the boot process.

questions.question: Who developed the C programming language?
questions.fact: Dennis Ritchie developed the C programming language at Bell Labs between 1969 and 1973.
questions.hint: This computer scientist also co-developed the Unix operating system.

questions.question: Which company introduced the first microprocessor?
questions.fact: Intel introduced the first commercially available microprocessor, the 4004, in 1971.
questions.hint: This company is still one of the largest manufacturers of computer processors.

questions.question: What is the largest capacity of a single hard drive available as of 2024?
questions.fact: As of 2024, the largest commercially available hard drive capacity is 20 TB, with companies like Seagate and Western Digital offering such drives.
questions.hint: Hard drive capacities have been steadily increasing, with the largest drives now offering this impressive storage size.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of colors supported by the VGA standard?
questions.fact: The VGA (Video Graphics Array) standard, introduced in 1987, supports a maximum of 256 colors in its highest resolution mode.
questions.hint: This color depth was a significant improvement over earlier standards and is still used in some contexts today.

questions.question: Which company developed the first computer with a graphical user interface (GUI)?
questions.fact: Xerox developed the Alto, the first computer with a graphical user interface, at their Palo Alto Research Center (PARC) in 1973.
questions.hint: This company's innovations at their Palo Alto Research Center influenced many future computer designs.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a RAID system in a computer?
questions.fact: RAID (Redundant Array of Independent Disks) systems are used to improve data storage reliability and/or increase I/O performance.
questions.hint: This technology combines multiple disk drive components into a logical unit for data redundancy and performance.

questions.question: What type of technology is used in Solid-State Drives (SSDs)?
questions.fact: SSDs use NAND Flash Memory, which allows for faster read and write speeds compared to traditional hard disk drives.
questions.hint: This type of memory retains data even when power is removed and has no moving parts.

questions.question: Who invented the first computer virus, and what was it called?
questions.fact: Bob Thomas created the Creeper virus in 1971 as an experimental self-replicating program.
questions.hint: This early virus was created in 1971 and was not malicious in nature.

questions.question: What was the original name of Microsoft Windows?
questions.fact: Microsoft's original name for Windows was 'Interface Manager', but it was changed before the product's release in 1985.
questions.hint: This name reflected the product's purpose of managing the user interface, but was changed before release.

questions.question: What was the name of the first internet browser?
questions.fact: The first web browser was called WorldWideWeb (later renamed Nexus) and was developed by Tim Berners-Lee in 1990.
questions.hint: This browser was developed by the creator of the World Wide Web himself.

questions.question: What is the difference between IPv4 and IPv6?
options: IPv6 has a larger address space and is more secure than IPv4
questions.fact: IPv6 has a much larger address space (128-bit) compared to IPv4 (32-bit) and includes built-in security features.
questions.hint: The newer version was developed to address limitations in the older version, particularly regarding available addresses.

questions.question: Who is credited with inventing the World Wide Web?
questions.fact: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989 while working at CERN.
questions.hint: This British computer scientist proposed and implemented the first successful communication between a client and server via the Internet.

questions.question: What does 'DNS' stand for in the context of networking?
questions.fact: DNS (Domain Name System) translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses.
questions.hint: This system is often described as the 'phone book' of the Internet.

questions.question: In the context of the internet, what does 'VPN' stand for?
questions.fact: A VPN (Virtual Private Network) extends a private network across a public network, enabling users to send and receive data as if their devices were directly connected to the private network.
questions.hint: This technology is often used to secure internet connections and access region-restricted content.

questions.question: What does the term 'Net Neutrality' refer to?
options: The principle that all internet traffic should be treated equally
A type of internet security protocol
A method of balancing network load
The idea that the internet should be free for everyone
questions.fact: Net Neutrality is the principle that internet service providers should treat all data on the internet equally, without discriminating or charging differently based on user, content, website, platform, application, type of equipment, or method of communication.
questions.hint: This principle advocates for equal treatment of all internet traffic by service providers.

questions.question: What is the main function of the HyperText Markup Language (HTML)?
options: To structure content on the web
questions.fact: HTML is used to structure content on the web, defining the basic structure and content of web pages.
questions.hint: This language uses tags to define the structure and content of web pages.

questions.question: Which company created the first commercial Internet search engine?
questions.fact: Yahoo! was founded in 1994 and became the first popular search engine on the World Wide Web.
questions.hint: This company started as a web directory before becoming a major internet portal and search engine.

questions.question: What is the largest file size that can be sent in an email attachment in most email services?
questions.fact: Most email services, including Gmail and Outlook, have a limit of 25 MB for email attachments.
questions.hint: This size limit is common across many popular email services to manage server load and storage.

questions.question: What is the default port for HTTP?
questions.fact: Port 80 is the default port for HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) traffic on the web.
questions.hint: This well-known port is used for unencrypted web traffic.

questions.question: Who is known as the 'father of cryptography'?
questions.fact: Claude Shannon is often referred to as the 'father of cryptography' due to his foundational work in information theory and cryptography.
questions.hint: This mathematician and electrical engineer made significant contributions to information theory and cryptography in the mid-20th century.

questions.question: What is the difference between symmetric and asymmetric encryption?
options: Symmetric uses one key, asymmetric uses two
Symmetric is faster, asymmetric is more secure
Symmetric uses the same key for encryption and decryption, while asymmetric uses a public and private key pair
questions.fact: Symmetric encryption uses the same key for both encryption and decryption, while asymmetric encryption uses a pair of public and private keys.
questions.hint: The key difference lies in how many keys are used and how they are applied in the encryption and decryption process.

questions.question: What does 'SSL' stand for in secure web browsing?
questions.fact: SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) is a standard security technology for establishing an encrypted link between a server and a client.
questions.hint: This protocol ensures that all data passed between the web server and browser remains private.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a firewall in a network?
options: To monitor and control incoming and outgoing network traffic
questions.fact: A firewall is a network security device that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.
questions.hint: This security measure acts as a barrier between trusted internal networks and untrusted external networks.

questions.question: In which year was the first major computer worm, 'Morris Worm,' released?
questions.fact: The Morris Worm, one of the first computer worms distributed via the Internet, was released on November 2, 1988.
questions.hint: This worm was created by Robert Tappan Morris and unintentionally caused major disruptions to the early Internet.

questions.question: What is the main function of an Intrusion Detection System (IDS)?
options: To detect unauthorized access or attacks on a network
questions.fact: An Intrusion Detection System (IDS) monitors network traffic for suspicious activity and issues alerts when such activity is discovered.
questions.hint: This system is designed to identify potential security breaches, typically through network or system abuse.

questions.question: What type of malware encrypts a user's files and demands payment for their release?
questions.fact: Ransomware is a type of malicious software that encrypts a victim's files and demands a ransom payment for the decryption key.
questions.hint: This type of malware 'holds' files for 'ransom' until a payment is made.

questions.question: What is the term for a type of cyber attack where attackers try to overwhelm a server with traffic?
questions.fact: A DDoS (Distributed Denial of Service) attack attempts to disrupt normal traffic of a targeted server, service or network by overwhelming the target or its surrounding infrastructure with a flood of Internet traffic.
questions.hint: This attack aims to make a service unavailable by flooding it with requests from multiple sources.

questions.question: Which encryption algorithm is most commonly used in modern secure communications?
questions.fact: AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) is widely adopted and supported in both hardware and software to encrypt sensitive data.
questions.hint: This symmetric encryption algorithm was established by the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) in 2001.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI)?
options: To manage digital keys and certificates for secure communication
questions.fact: A Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) is a set of roles, policies, hardware, software and procedures needed to create, manage, distribute, use, store and revoke digital certificates and manage public-key encryption.
questions.hint: This system is crucial for secure electronic transfer of information for various network activities.

questions.question: What does the acronym 'AI' stand for in the context of computer science?
questions.fact: AI stands for Artificial Intelligence, which refers to the simulation of human intelligence in machines that are programmed to think and learn like humans.
questions.hint: This field of computer science aims to create intelligent machines that can perform tasks that typically require human intelligence.

questions.question: Who is the co-creator of the Turing Test?
questions.fact: Alan Turing proposed the Turing Test in his 1950 paper 'Technology Machinery and Intelligence' as a method of inquiry in artificial intelligence.
questions.hint: This British mathematician and computer scientist is considered one of the fathers of computer science and artificial intelligence.

questions.question: What is the difference between supervised and unsupervised machine learning?
options: Supervised learning is faster, unsupervised is more accurate
Supervised learning uses labeled data, while unsupervised learning uses unlabeled data
Supervised learning is for classification, unsupervised is for regression
questions.fact: In supervised learning, the algorithm learns on a labeled dataset, while unsupervised learning algorithms learn on unlabeled datasets.
questions.hint: The key difference lies in whether the data the algorithm learns from is pre-labeled or not.

questions.question: What is the name of the AI language model developed by OpenAI?
questions.fact: GPT-3 (Generative Pre-trained Transformer 3) is a language model developed by OpenAI, known for its ability to produce human-like text.
questions.hint: This large language model is known for its impressive text generation capabilities and has been widely discussed in AI circles.

questions.question: What does the term 'neural network' refer to in machine learning?
options: A network of computers working together
A network of algorithms inspired by the human brain's structure, used to recognize patterns
questions.fact: In machine learning, a neural network is a series of algorithms that endeavors to recognize underlying relationships in a set of data through a process that mimics the way the human brain operates.
questions.hint: This concept in machine learning is inspired by the structure and function of biological neural networks.

questions.question: Which algorithm is commonly used in decision tree learning?
questions.fact: ID3 (Iterative Dichotomiser 3) is an algorithm used to generate a decision tree from a dataset, invented by Ross Quinlan.
questions.hint: This algorithm is used to generate a decision tree from a dataset, using the concept of information entropy.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of reinforcement learning in AI?
options: To enable an agent to learn by interacting with its environment and receiving feedback
questions.fact: Reinforcement learning is a type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by taking actions in an environment to maximize some notion of cumulative reward.
questions.hint: This type of learning is based on the idea of learning through trial and error, much like how humans and animals learn.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between deep learning and traditional machine learning?
options: Deep learning is supervised, traditional machine learning is unsupervised
Deep learning uses large neural networks with many layers, while traditional machine learning often uses simpler models
Deep learning is slower, traditional machine learning is faster
questions.fact: Deep learning uses artificial neural networks with multiple layers (deep neural networks) to progressively extract higher-level features from raw input, while traditional machine learning relies on simpler models and often requires more feature engineering.
questions.hint: The key difference lies in the complexity of the models and how features are extracted from the data.

questions.question: In AI, what is 'overfitting'?
options: When a model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern
When a model learns the training data too well, including noise, which reduces its ability to generalize
When a model is trained on too much data
When a model takes too long to train
questions.fact: Overfitting occurs when a model learns the detail and noise in the training data to the extent that it negatively impacts the performance of the model on new data.
questions.hint: This phenomenon results in a model that performs well on training data but poorly on unseen data.

questions.question: What was the name of the first AI program to defeat a human world champion in a game of Go?
questions.fact: AlphaGo, developed by Google DeepMind, was the first computer program to defeat a professional human Go player in 2015.
questions.hint: This AI program made headlines when it defeated the world champion Lee Sedol in 2016.

questions.question: Which programming language was developed by James Gosling and is used in Android development?
questions.fact: Java was developed by James Gosling at Sun Microsystems (now owned by Oracle) and is widely used in Android app development.
questions.hint: This language is known for its 'write once, run anywhere' philosophy and is widely used in enterprise environments.

questions.question: What does 'OOP' stand for in programming languages?
questions.fact: OOP stands for Object-Oriented Programming, a programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects' which can contain data and code.
questions.hint: This programming paradigm uses 'objects' to design applications and programs.

questions.question: What is the purpose of version control in software development?
options: To manage changes to the source code and track revisions
questions.fact: Version control systems are used to track changes in source code over time, allowing multiple developers to work together on projects and manage different versions of code.
questions.hint: This practice helps developers manage changes and collaborate on projects over time.

questions.question: Which software development methodology uses an iterative and incremental approach?
questions.fact: Agile methodology is an iterative and incremental approach to software development that emphasizes flexibility, customer collaboration, and rapid delivery of working software.
questions.hint: This methodology values responding to change over following a plan and is popular for its flexibility.

questions.question: What is the main difference between a compiled and an interpreted programming language?
options: Compiled languages are faster, interpreted languages are slower
Compiled languages require a separate compilation step, interpreted languages are executed directly
Compiled languages are more secure, interpreted languages are less secure
questions.fact: A compiled language is converted into machine code before execution, while an interpreted language is executed line by line by an interpreter.
questions.hint: The key difference lies in how the code is translated into machine-readable instructions.

questions.question: What does the term 'API' stand for in software development?
questions.fact: API stands for Application Programming Interface, which is a set of protocols, routines, and tools for building software applications.
questions.hint: This term refers to a set of definitions and protocols for building and integrating application software.

questions.question: Who invented the JavaScript programming language?
questions.fact: JavaScript was created by Brendan Eich in 1995 while he was working at Netscape Communications Corporation.
questions.hint: This language was created in just 10 days and has become one of the core technologies of the World Wide Web.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'try-catch' block in programming?
options: To handle exceptions and errors in code
questions.fact: The try-catch block is used in many programming languages to handle exceptions and errors that may occur during program execution.
questions.hint: This construct is used to gracefully handle unexpected situations in code execution.

questions.question: Which programming language is used primarily for data analysis and scientific Technology?
questions.fact: Python has become the go-to language for data analysis and scientific Technology due to its simplicity and powerful libraries like NumPy and Pandas.
questions.hint: This language is known for its readability and extensive libraries for data manipulation and analysis.

questions.question: In which year was Python created?
questions.fact: Python was created by Guido van Rossum and first released in 1991.
questions.hint: This popular programming language was created in the early 1990s and named after the British comedy group Monty Python.

questions.question: What is the term for a robot that can perform tasks autonomously without human intervention?
questions.fact: An autonomous robot is a robot that performs behaviors or tasks with a high degree of autonomy, without external control.
questions.hint: This type of robot can operate independently and make decisions based on its programming and sensors.

questions.question: Who is known as the 'father of robotics'?
questions.fact: George Devol is often referred to as the 'father of robotics' for his invention of the first industrial robot, Unimate, in 1954.
questions.hint: This American inventor patented the first programmable robotic arm, which was used in General Motors assembly lines in 1961.

questions.question: What is the name of the humanoid robot developed by Hanson Robotics?
questions.fact: Sophia is a social humanoid robot developed by Hanson Robotics, known for her human-like appearance and behavior.
questions.hint: This robot gained significant media attention and became the first robot to receive citizenship of a country (Saudi Arabia).

questions.question: Which company is famous for creating the 'Atlas' humanoid robot?
questions.fact: Atlas is a bipedal humanoid robot primarily developed by Boston Dynamics, with funding and oversight from the U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA).
questions.hint: This company is known for its advanced robotics research and viral videos of robots performing impressive feats.

questions.question: What is the difference between industrial robots and service robots?
options: Industrial robots are larger, service robots are smaller
Industrial robots are used in manufacturing, while service robots assist in tasks like cleaning or customer service
Industrial robots are more expensive, service robots are cheaper
questions.fact: Industrial robots are typically used in manufacturing and production settings, while service robots are designed to assist humans in various service-oriented tasks.
questions.hint: The key difference lies in their application and the environments in which they operate.

questions.question: Which company developed the first commercially successful autonomous car?
questions.fact: Waymo, a subsidiary of Alphabet Inc. (Google's parent company), is widely recognized as the first company to develop a commercially successful autonomous car.
questions.hint: This company started as Google's self-driving car project before becoming its own entity under Alphabet Inc.

questions.question: What is the main advantage of collaborative robots (cobots)?
options: They are faster than traditional robots
They work alongside humans in a shared workspace
questions.fact: Collaborative robots, or cobots, are designed to work safely alongside humans in a shared workspace, enhancing productivity and flexibility in various industries.
questions.hint: These robots are designed with safety features that allow them to operate in close proximity to human workers.

questions.question: What is the term for robots that are used in manufacturing processes?
questions.fact: Industrial robots are programmable mechanical devices used in manufacturing processes to perform tasks such as welding, painting, assembly, and material handling.
questions.hint: These robots are commonly used in factories and production lines to automate various tasks.

questions.question: What is 'robotic process automation' (RPA)?
options: The use of physical robots in manufacturing
The use of robots or AI to automate repetitive business processes
questions.fact: Robotic Process Automation (RPA) is the use of software 'robots' to automate repetitive, rule-based tasks typically performed by humans in business processes.
questions.hint: This technology is used to automate routine tasks in business operations, often in office or administrative settings.

questions.question: Which technology is primarily used for creating 3D printed objects?
questions.fact: Additive manufacturing, commonly known as 3D printing, is a process of creating three-dimensional objects by depositing materials layer by layer.
questions.hint: This technology builds objects by adding material, as opposed to subtractive manufacturing methods.

questions.question: What is the name of the virtual currency created by an anonymous person (or group of people) named Satoshi Nakamoto?
questions.fact: Bitcoin, created in 2009 by an unknown person or group using the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto, was the first decentralized cryptocurrency.
questions.hint: This cryptocurrency is often referred to as digital gold and has the largest market capitalization among all cryptocurrencies.

questions.question: What is the main function of blockchain technology?
options: To provide a secure, decentralized ledger for transactions
questions.fact: Blockchain is a decentralized, distributed ledger technology that records transactions across many computers so that the record cannot be altered retroactively without the alteration of all subsequent blocks.
questions.hint: This technology is the underlying system for most cryptocurrencies and has applications beyond digital currencies.

questions.question: What does the term 'Quantum Technology' refer to?
options: Technology based on the principles of quantum mechanics, using quantum bits (qubits)
A theoretical form of Technology that doesn't exist yet
questions.fact: Quantum Technology uses quantum-mechanical phenomena, such as superposition and entanglement, to perform operations on data using quantum bits or qubits.
questions.hint: This type of Technology leverages principles from quantum physics to perform certain computations much faster than classical computers.

questions.question: Which company is leading the development of quantum Technology technology as of 2024?
questions.fact: While many companies are working on quantum Technology, IBM has been at the forefront with its IBM Quantum Experience and the development of quantum computers available through the cloud.
questions.hint: This company has been a pioneer in Technology technology for decades and has made significant strides in quantum Technology research and development.

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of 5G networks over 4G?
questions.fact: 5G networks offer significantly faster data transfer speeds and lower latency compared to 4G, enabling new applications in areas like IoT, autonomous vehicles, and augmented reality.
questions.hint: This new generation of cellular technology promises to revolutionize mobile communications with its improved performance.

questions.question: What does the term 'Internet of Things' (IoT) refer to?
options: A network of physical devices that are connected to the internet and can communicate with each other
questions.fact: The Internet of Things (IoT) refers to the interconnected network of physical devices, vehicles, home appliances, and other items embedded with electronics, software, sensors, and network connectivity which enables these objects to collect and exchange data.
questions.hint: This concept involves everyday objects being connected to the internet and able to send and receive data.

questions.question: Which company developed the first commercial smart glasses called 'Google Glass'?
questions.fact: Google Glass, an optical head-mounted display designed in the shape of a pair of eyeglasses, was developed by Google and unveiled in 2013.
questions.hint: These smart glasses were developed by the company known for its popular search engine.

questions.question: What is the purpose of augmented reality (AR) technology?
options: To create fully immersive virtual environments
To overlay digital information on the real world through a device screen
questions.fact: Augmented Reality (AR) technology superimposes digital information on the user's view of the real world, enhancing their perception of reality.
questions.hint: This technology adds digital elements to a live view, often by using the camera on a smartphone or other device.

questions.question: What is the most commonly used programming language in the development of smart contract applications on Ethereum blockchain?
questions.fact: Solidity is a contract-oriented, high-level language for implementing smart contracts on various blockchain platforms, most notably, Ethereum.
questions.hint: This language was specifically designed for writing smart contracts on the Ethereum blockchain.

questions.question: What is the name of the first fully autonomous cargo ship that was developed and tested?
questions.fact: The Yara Birkeland, developed in Norway, is considered the world's first fully electric and autonomous container ship, designed to reduce emissions and transportation costs.
